items.name: React
items.description:
React has changed a lot over the years since I started to learn it in 2017. From class components to function components, and now server components and even a compiler. It's been cool to see it continue to develop and keep up with the development.

React is definitely my go-to framwork if I'm going to build a front-end and I've used it for several of my hobby projects. I also used it while I was working on a contract basis for my friend since the main tracking website was built with React and I sometimes had to implement new features or re-factor existing code.

items.name: TypeScript
items.description: TypeScript was one of the things I stayed away from for the longest time because I didn't really feel like I needed it. But I guess after getting into typed languages such a Golang and C# I started to see the value in it. And after one too many 'cannot read property of undefined' errors I decided to pick up TypeScript and used it for my Kombucha Brewery project. I think it's especially good when you can get that fullstack end-to-end type safety.

items.name: Node.js
items.description: Node.js is probably where I feel the most comfortable and have the most coding experience. I really like how fast you can build something and the flexibility of it, as well as the enourmous amount of tooling available.

items.name: Go
items.description: Go is the first typed and compiled language I learned. And I think it's a perfect first pick. It's quite simple but yet powerful. And I love that basically everything you need is included in the standard library. But I do think Go can get a bit overly verbose sometimes. Another great thing is the concurrency model.

items.name: Microsoft SQL Server
items.description: I used to be a Postgres and SQlite kinda guy, but after being forced to work so much in SQL server at my current job, I actually really started to like it. I dig all the functionality in SSMS and keep finding new stuff in there all the time. I utilize stored procedures a lot, but also functions and triggers.

items.name: Postgres
items.description: Great open source database when you need a bit more features than SQlite. I used it for several of my hobby projects such as Top XYZ and Kombucha Brewery.

items.name: Git
items.description: Git is such a core skill as a software developer, and I'm happy I started using it from the very beginning of my programming journey.

items.name: AI assisted programming
items.description:
I'm consistently trying to stay at the forefront of new technology. Keeping up with new AI developments is no easy task as new models and tools keep popping up.

I don't think AI will replace programmers, but I do think hand writing code professionally will eventually become a thing of the past, unless it's done as a hobby. Just as blacksmithing or other professions of the past has changed, programmers will need to evolve.

items.name: Linux
items.description: Linux is an amazing development environment as it's free, open-source, stable, secure, customizable and extremely powerful with great developer tooling. Even though there are many different distibutions of Linux I've so far only used the debian based Ubuntu.

items.name: HTML
items.description:
HTML is the corner stone of the world wide web. It is used to organize and categorize the content of a website.

I have been using HTML since 2017 and I feel very comfortable using it.

items.name: CSS
items.description:
CSS is the paint brush for the web.

I rarely use vanilla CSS these days as I prefer tailwind where I can use pre defined classes to get stuff done quicker.

items.name: Python
items.description: People often complain that Python is slow. But honestly, for many use cases you don't need the execution speed you can get with many other languages. What you get instead is very high productivity. I love it for making simple tools for myself.
